conclusion: Define variable linear motion as motion where velocity changes over time, identified by a non-constant slope on a v-t graph.
The v-t graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time with three segments: 0-1s, 1-2s, 2-3s.
Segment 1 (0 to 1 second): Velocity is constant at 2 m/s, slope is zero.
Segment 2 (1 to 2 seconds): Velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s, slope is negative and constant.
Segment 3 (2 to 3 seconds): Velocity decreases from 0 m/s to -2 m/s, slope remains negative and constant.
In the first segment (0 to 1 second), velocity is constant, so no variable linear motion.
In the second and third segments (1 to 3 seconds), velocity changes uniformly, indicating variable linear motion.
The particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, specifically from 1 to 3 seconds.
